recipes.name: Kadubu Idli (Steamed Jackfruit Leaf Idli)
ingredients: 200 grams whole husked black gram (urad dal)
1½ cups water, for soaking urad dal
1½ cups water, for soaking idli rava
1¼ cups water, for grinding urad dal
directions: Step 1: Rinse the urad dal in a bowl a couple of times. Soak in 1½ cups of water, cover, and set aside for 4 hours.
Step 2: Rinse the idli rava in a bowl by filling it with water, stirring, and discarding the water. Repeat this process once or twice. Then, soak the idli rava in 1½ cups of water for 3-4 hours.
Step 3: Drain the soaked urad dal and add it to a grinder jar along with 1¼ cups of water. Grind to a smooth and fluffy batter.
Step 4: Transfer the urad dal batter to a large bowl or pan.
Step 5: Squeeze the soaked idli rava in handfuls to remove excess water. Add the squeezed idli rava to the urad dal batter, ensuring all the rava is well squeezed.

Step 6: Mix the batter thoroughly with a spoon or spatula until there are no lumps. Cover and let it ferment for 8-9 hours, or until it develops a pleasant sour aroma and tiny bubbles. Fermentation time may vary depending on the climate and temperature.
Step 7: Prepare the jackfruit leaf cups (kotte). Rinse the leaves well and dry them with a clean cloth. Use leaves of similar size.
Step 8: Take two leaves and overlap them, stem sides facing outwards. Secure them together using a thin coconut or bamboo stick.
Step 9: Add two more leaves on top, overlapping each one and securing with the stick. This forms the kotte.
Step 10: Repeat this process to make 40-50 kotte, ensuring they are tightly sealed to prevent leakage.
Step 11: Once the batter is fermented, add salt and mix well.
Step 12: Heat 2-2½ cups of water in a large pot or pan with a stand or rack inside.
Step 13: Arrange the jackfruit leaf cups in a steamer pan.
Step 14: Gently pour or spoon the batter into the cups.
Step 15: Place the steamer pan over the pot of boiling water, cover, and steam for 12-15 minutes over medium to medium-high heat.
Step 16: Check for doneness with a skewer; it should come out clean. Remove the lid and let cool for 2-3 minutes.
Step 17: Gently remove the sticks and leaves from each kotte.
Step 18: Serve the kadubu idli hot or warm with coconut chutney, sambar, or idli-dosa podi.

recipes.name: Soft and Spongy Idli
directions: Step 1: Rinse the urad dal and fenugreek seeds thoroughly 2-3 times. In a bowl, combine the urad dal, fenugreek seeds, and poha. Add 1 cup of water and soak for 4-5 hours, or until the dal doubles in size.
Step 2: Rinse both the parboiled and basmati rice together 3-4 times until the water runs clear. In a separate bowl, combine both types of rice, add 2 cups of water, and soak for 4-5 hours.
Step 3: Drain the urad dal mixture, reserving the soaking water. Transfer the drained dal and fenugreek seeds to a blender or wet grinder.
Step 4: Add 1/2 cup of the reserved soaking water to the blender and grind until smooth. Gradually add more water as needed, about 1/2 cup total, until the mixture is light, fluffy, and smooth.
Step 5: Transfer the ground urad dal mixture to a large container.
Step 6: Drain the rice and add it to the blender. Grind with about 1/2 cup of water until slightly coarse.
Step 7: Transfer the ground rice mixture to the container with the urad dal mixture.

Step 8: Add salt to the combined batter and mix well. The batter should not be too thick or too thin. Cover the container and let it ferment in a warm place for 8-10 hours, or until it doubles in size.
Step 9: Stir the fermented batter. It should be bubbly. Check the salt and add more if needed.
Step 10: Pour 1-2 glasses of water into a steamer and heat over medium heat. Grease idli molds with oil.
Step 11: Pour the batter into the greased idli molds. Place the molds in the steamer, cover, and steam for 10 minutes.
Step 12: Insert a knife or toothpick into the center of an idli to check for doneness. If it comes out clean, the idlis are cooked. If not, steam for a few more minutes and check again.
Step 13: Remove the idli molds from the steamer and let them cool slightly. Use a wet spoon to remove the idlis from the molds.
Step 14: Serve the idlis hot with sambar and coconut chutney.

recipes.name: Spicy Podi Idli
ingredients: A small sprig of curry leaves
directions: Step 1: Prepare the Idlis: Pour idli batter into a mini idli mold and steam for 8-10 minutes. If using a steamer with a cloth, use it for softer idlis. Alternatively, pour the batter directly into the mold.
Step 2: Mix Idlis with Podi and Oil: In a mixing bowl, combine the steamed mini idlis, gingelly oil, and idli podi. Mix well and set aside.
Step 3: Sauté Aromatics and Vegetables: Heat oil in a kadai (wok). Add mustard seeds and curry leaves, and let them splutter.
Step 4: Add Vegetables: Add finely chopped onion and ginger-garlic paste to the kadai. Sauté for a few minutes until the onions turn golden brown. Then, add grated carrot and chopped capsicum.
Step 5: Cook Vegetables: Sauté the vegetables for a few minutes until the raw smell disappears. Add salt to taste.
Step 6: Combine Idlis and Vegetables: Add the podi-coated idlis to the kadai and toss well with the sautéed vegetables.
Step 7: Garnish and Serve: Finally, add finely chopped coriander leaves and ghee-fried cashews. Give a quick stir and remove from heat.

recipes.name: Mini Idli with Sambar
ingredients: As needed Tiffin Sambar / Arachuvitta Sambar / Sambar
directions: Step 1: Prepare the idli batter. Using a small spoon, fill each cavity of a mini idli mold with the batter.
Step 2: Carefully place the mini idli mold in an idli steamer containing water up to 1/4th of its height. Steam for 8-10 minutes.
Step 3: After steaming, turn off the heat and sprinkle a teaspoon of water over the idlis. Let them rest for 5 minutes. Then, gently loosen the idlis from the mold using a spoon and set them aside.
Step 4: In a serving plate, add a ladle of sambar. Arrange the mini idlis on top and pour more sambar over them. Drizzle with ghee and garnish with chopped onions and coriander leaves.

recipes.name: Instant Rava Idli
ingredients: 1 teaspoon chana dal (split and husked chickpeas)
½ teaspoon salt, or to taste
1 cup (175 grams) rava (semolina, cream of wheat)
½ to ¾ cup water, as needed
1 teaspoon eno (fruit salt) or ½ teaspoon baking soda
directions: Step 1: Heat the ghee in a pan over medium-low heat. Add the halved cashews and fry until golden brown, stirring frequently. Remove the cashews with a slotted spoon and set aside.
Step 2: In the same pan, add the mustard seeds and let them splutter over medium-low heat.
Step 3: Add the chana dal and fry until golden brown and crunchy, stirring frequently. Add the cumin seeds and fry for 4-5 seconds.
Step 4: Add the curry leaves, asafoetida, ginger, and green chili. Mix well and fry for 10 seconds over low heat.
Step 5: Add the rava and roast, stirring frequently, until aromatic and lightly colored (not browned), about 5-7 minutes. The grains should appear separate. Remove from heat and let cool slightly.
Step 6: Add the grated carrots, chopped coriander leaves, and salt to the roasted rava. Mix well.
Step 7: Add the yogurt and ½ cup of water. Mix well. If the batter is too thick, add more water, up to ¾ cup total. The batter should have a medium consistency.
Step 8: Cover the batter and let it rest for 20 minutes.
Step 9: Grease an idli steamer or mold with oil or ghee. Place a fried cashew in the center of each mold. Heat 2-2.5 cups of water in a steamer or pot with a trivet or rack until boiling.
Step 10: After 20 minutes, check the batter's consistency. If it has thickened, add 1-2 tablespoons of water. Sprinkle the eno or baking soda evenly over the batter and mix quickly.
Step 11: Pour the batter into the prepared molds. Place the molds in the steamer and cover. Steam for 10-12 minutes.

Step 12: Check for doneness by inserting a toothpick into an idli. It should come out clean. Remove the idli plates from the steamer and let them rest for 3-4 minutes before removing the idlis with a spoon.
Step 13: Serve the rava idli hot with sambar and coconut chutney.

recipes.name: Crispy Idli Fry
ingredients: 5-6 leftover idlis, sliced into 1/2-inch thick fries
Black salt or salt, to taste
Fresh coriander leaves, chopped, for garnish
directions: Step 1: Prepare the Idlis: Slice the leftover idlis lengthwise into fries about 1/2-inch thick.
Step 2: Dust with Corn Flour: Lightly sprinkle the idli fries with corn flour, ensuring they are evenly coated.
Step 3: Heat the Oil: Heat the vegetable oil in a large pan over medium heat. The oil is ready when a small piece of idli dropped in sizzles gently.
Step 4: Fry the Idlis: Carefully place 3-4 idli fries in the hot oil, ensuring not to overcrowd the pan. Fry until golden brown and crispy on both sides, about 2-3 minutes per side.

Step 5: Drain and Season: Remove the fried idli fries with a slotted spoon and place them on a plate lined with absorbent paper towels to remove excess oil. While still hot, sprinkle with pav bhaji masala, chaat masala, idli podi powder (if using), and salt to taste.
Step 6: Garnish and Serve: Garnish the crispy idli fries with freshly chopped coriander leaves. Serve immediately with your favorite chutney or dipping sauce.

recipes.name: Mini Pepper Idli
ingredients: A small sprig of curry leaves
directions: Step 1: Prepare the Idlis: Pour idli batter into a mini idli mold and steam for 8-10 minutes. If using a steamer with a cloth, use it for softer idlis.  Alternatively, pour the batter directly into the mold.

Step 2: Dry Roast and Grind Spices: While the idlis are steaming, dry roast peppercorns and fennel seeds until fragrant. Grind them to a semi-coarse powder using a mortar and pestle or spice grinder. Set aside.

Step 3: Sauté Aromatics and Vegetables: Heat oil in a pan. Add garlic and roast until slightly browned. Add curry leaves and let them splutter. Add onion and fry until golden brown. Add capsicum and toss well.

Step 4: Add Spices and Idlis: Add the ground pepper-fennel mixture and garam masala powder to the pan. Mix well, add salt to taste, and fry for 3 minutes. Add the steamed mini idlis and sprinkle a little water to help the flavors combine. Toss until the idlis are nicely coated with the spices.
Step 5: Garnish and Serve: Garnish with coriander leaves and serve hot.

recipes.name: Tawa Fried Idli

recipes.name: Crispy Kaima Idli
ingredients: 6 leftover Idlis, cut into small cubes
directions: Step 1: Deep fry the cubed idlis in hot oil until golden brown and crispy. Set aside.
Step 2: Heat 2 teaspoons of oil in a pan. Add the curry leaves, fennel seeds powder, and green chili. Sauté until fragrant.
Step 3: Add the chopped onion and ginger-garlic paste. Sauté until the onion turns light brown.
Step 4: Add the tomato puree, Kashmiri chili powder, coriander powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix well.
Step 5: Cook until the raw smell of tomatoes disappears.
Step 6: Pressure cook the green peas for 2 whistles until tender. Add the cooked peas and cubed capsicum to the pan.
Step 7: Stir well, add 1/2 cup of water, and simmer for 3 minutes.
Step 8: Gently add the fried idlis to the pan and toss to coat them evenly with the masala. Be careful not to mash them.
Step 9: Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Remove from heat and add lemon juice.

recipes.name: Authentic Rava Idli
ingredients: 1/4 teaspoon Baking Soda (or 1 sachet Eno Fruit Salt or 1 teaspoon Eno)
directions: Step 1: In a mixing bowl, combine the semolina, salt, and yogurt. Mix well.

Step 2: Gradually add water to the dry ingredients, stirring until a smooth paste forms. If the mixture appears too dry, add a little more water, a tablespoon at a time, until the desired consistency is reached.
Step 3: Add the baking soda (or Eno Fruit Salt/Eno) to the batter and gently stir. Do not overmix.
Step 4: Grease the idli molds with canola oil.
Step 5: Pour a small amount of batter into each greased idli mold. Steam in an idli steamer for 5-7 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.
Step 6: Once cooked, allow the idlis to cool slightly before carefully removing them from the molds. Serve hot with sambar and chutney.

video_script.title: Authentic Rava Idli: A Quick and Delicious South Indian Breakfast
video_script.description: Learn how to make soft and fluffy Rava Idli, a popular South Indian breakfast dish, with this easy-to-follow recipe.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a plate of perfectly cooked, fluffy Rava Idlis, served with sambar and chutney. Steam is gently rising from the idlis. The background features a blurred kitchen setting.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome! Today, we're making Rava Idli, a quick and delicious South Indian breakfast. These steamed semolina cakes are light, fluffy, and perfect with sambar and chutney.

scenes.image_prompt: Overhead shot of all ingredients neatly arranged on a wooden table: 2 cups semolina, 4 tablespoons yogurt, 1/2 teaspoon salt, 1 tablespoon canola oil, 1/4 teaspoon baking soda, and 1 cup water.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: 2 cups of semolina, 4 tablespoons of yogurt, half a teaspoon of salt, 1 tablespoon of canola oil for greasing, 1/4 teaspoon of baking soda, and 1 cup of water.

scenes.image_prompt: A mixing bowl with semolina, salt, and yogurt being combined with a whisk.
scenes.voice_over: In a mixing bowl, combine the semolina, salt, and yogurt. Mix these ingredients well.

scenes.image_prompt: Water being gradually added to the semolina mixture while stirring continuously with a whisk.
scenes.voice_over: Gradually add water to the dry ingredients, stirring until a smooth paste forms. If the batter is too dry, add a little more water, a tablespoon at a time.

scenes.image_prompt: Baking soda being gently folded into the idli batter.
scenes.voice_over: Now, add the baking soda or Eno Fruit Salt to the batter and gently stir. Don't overmix. This will make the idlis light and airy.

scenes.image_prompt: Greasing idli molds with canola oil using a brush or a spray.
scenes.voice_over: Grease the idli molds with canola oil. This prevents the idlis from sticking.

scenes.image_prompt: Pouring the idli batter into the greased idli molds.
scenes.voice_over: Pour the batter into the greased molds, filling each about three-quarters full.

scenes.voice_over: Steam the idlis for 5-7 minutes in an idli steamer, or until a toothpick inserted comes out clean.

scenes.voice_over: Once cooked, let the idlis cool slightly before carefully removing them from the molds.

scenes.voice_over: Serve your hot and fluffy Rava Idlis with sambar and chutney. Enjoy! Each serving contains about 200 calories, 5 grams of protein, 40 grams of carbs, and 5 grams of fat.

cooking_tips: Do not overmix the batter after adding the baking soda/Eno, as this can result in dense idlis.
Use a good quality idli steamer for best results.
If you don't have an idli steamer, you can use a pressure cooker with a steamer insert.
Serve immediately with your favorite chutneys and sambar for a complete and satisfying meal.

recipes.name: Idli and Dosa Batter
directions: Step 1: Soak the idli rice, urad dal, and fenugreek seeds separately in enough water for at least 2-3 hours.

Step 2: Drain the water from the urad dal and fenugreek seeds. Add them to a grinder, being careful not to overload the grinder. Sprinkle water as needed while grinding for a total of 40 minutes, ensuring a light and fluffy batter.  It's helpful to monitor the grinding process, especially towards the end, to achieve the desired consistency.

Step 3: Transfer the urad dal batter to a large container. Drain the water from the soaked rice and add it to the grinder. Sprinkle with water and grind for about 30 minutes, or until smooth with a slightly coarse texture. The rice batter should be slightly thicker than the urad dal batter.
Step 4: Combine the rice and urad dal batters in the large container. Add salt and mix well. Cover and let the batter ferment in a warm place for 10-12 hours, or until it rises and becomes porous.
Step 5: For idli, pour a ladleful of batter into each mold of an idli steamer and steam for 10-12 minutes. To remove, sprinkle a little water around the edges of the idlis and gently slide them out.

Step 6: For dosa, heat a lightly oiled griddle or flat pan. Pour a ladleful of batter onto the hot griddle and spread it thinly in a circular motion. Cook until golden brown and crispy, flipping once halfway through.

recipes.name: Savory Oats Idli
ingredients: 1 cup Instant Oats (such as Quaker Oats)
directions: Step 1: Dry roast the oats for 3 minutes, then set aside to cool completely. Once cooled, grind the oats into a fine powder.
Step 2: Dry roast the rava for 3-4 minutes, or until fragrant, then set aside.
Step 3: Heat a teaspoon of oil in a pan. Add the mustard seeds and let them splutter. Add the grated carrot, green chilies, and coriander leaves. Sauté until the raw smell of the carrot disappears.
Step 4: In a mixing bowl, combine the ground oats, roasted rava, curd, salt, hing, baking soda, and the sautéed carrot mixture.
Step 5: Add water as needed to achieve a batter consistency similar to regular idli batter.
Step 6: Grease idli plates with oil. Pour the batter into the greased plates using a ladle.
Step 7: Steam the idlis for 10-12 minutes, or until cooked through. Serve hot with your favorite chutney.

recipes.name: Rava Idli
ingredients: 3/4 teaspoon Baking Soda or Eno Fruit Salt
1/2 teaspoon Channa Dal, soaked for 15 minutes
directions: Step 1: Soak channa dal in water for 15 minutes. Set aside. Roast cashews in 1 teaspoon of ghee until golden brown and set aside. Reserve a few whole cashews.

Step 2: Heat oil and remaining ghee in a pan. Add mustard seeds, urad dal, and channa dal. Allow to splutter. Add turmeric powder, hing, and grated carrot. Sauté until the carrot softens and the raw smell disappears.
Step 3: Add semolina to the pan and roast for 3 minutes. Remove from heat and let it cool slightly.
Step 4: In a large bowl, combine the cooled semolina mixture with curd, broken cashews, chopped coriander leaves, and salt. Mix well.

Step 5: Add baking soda or Eno fruit salt to the batter and mix. The batter will become frothy. Gradually add water, mixing until the batter reaches an idli batter consistency. Do not let the batter sit for too long after mixing.
Step 6: Place a whole cashew upside down in each idli mold. Pour the batter immediately into the molds.
Step 7: Steam the idlis for 5-8 minutes. Insert a knife or fork into the center of an idli to check for doneness. If it comes out clean, the idlis are ready. If not, steam for a few more minutes.
Step 8: Allow the idlis to rest for 5 minutes before unmolding.

recipes.name: Split Green Moong Dal Idli
directions: Step 1: Wash and soak the urad dal and split green moong dal separately for at least 4-6 hours, or preferably overnight.
Step 2: Drain the water from both dals. Grind the urad dal into a smooth batter, adding water as needed to achieve a fluffy consistency.
Step 3: Grind the split green moong dal separately to a slightly coarse batter, adding water sparingly.  The moong dal batter doesn't need to be as smooth as the urad dal batter.
Step 4: Combine the two batters in a large container and mix well. Add salt and whisk thoroughly for about 2-3 minutes to aerate the batter.

Step 5: Cover the batter and let it ferment in a warm place for 8-12 hours, or until it rises and becomes light and airy. The fermentation time will depend on the temperature and humidity of your environment.
Step 6: Grease the idli molds with a little oil or cooking spray.
Step 7: Pour the fermented batter into the greased idli molds, filling them about ¾ full.
Step 8: Steam the idlis in a steamer for 10-12 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.
Step 9: Once cooked, let the idlis cool slightly before carefully removing them from the molds.
Step 10: Serve hot with chutney and sambar.

recipes.name: Onion Uttapam
ingredients: 1 cup Ponni Idli Rice (or any short-grain rice)
Water (for soaking, grinding, batter, and steaming)
directions: Step 1: Wash and soak the horse gram, urad dal, and methi seeds together for at least 4 hours.
Step 2: Wash and soak the rice separately for at least 2 hours.
Step 3: Grind the soaked dal mixture into a smooth batter. Grind the soaked rice separately into a slightly coarser batter.
Step 4: Combine the dal and rice batters in a large container. Mix well with your hands.
Step 5: Cover and let the batter ferment for at least 8 hours, or preferably overnight, in a warm place.
Step 6: Once fermented, add salt to the batter and mix lightly. Adjust the consistency with water if needed.
Step 7: Heat a non-stick griddle or tawa. Lightly grease it with oil.
Step 8: Pour a ladleful of batter onto the hot griddle. Spread it gently into a thick circle.
Step 9: Sprinkle chopped onions, cilantro, and green chilies evenly over the uttapam.
Step 10: Drizzle a little oil around the edges of the uttapam.
Step 11: Cook for 2-3 minutes per side, or until golden brown and cooked through.
Step 12: Serve hot with your favorite chutney or sambar.

recipes.name: Steamed Rice Cakes (Idli)
ingredients: 2 tablespoons vegetable oil or canola oil
directions: Step 1: Rinse the rice and urad dal separately under cold water until the water runs clear. Soak them separately in enough water to cover them completely for at least 6-8 hours, or preferably overnight.

Step 2: Drain the soaked rice and urad dal. Grind the rice into a smooth paste, adding small amounts of water as needed. Grind the urad dal separately into a thick, fluffy paste, adding small amounts of water as needed.
Step 3: Combine the rice paste and urad dal paste in a large bowl. Add the salt and mix thoroughly.
Step 4: Cover the bowl and let the batter ferment in a warm place for 8-12 hours, or overnight. The batter will rise and become light and airy.
Step 5: Grease the idli molds with oil. Pour the fermented batter into the molds, filling them about three-fourths full.
Step 6: Pour 2 cups of water into a steamer or a large pot with a steaming rack. Heat the water over medium-high heat until it comes to a boil.
Step 7: Place the filled idli tray in the steamer or on the steaming rack. Cover and steam for 15-20 minutes.
Step 8: Insert a toothpick into the center of an idli. If it comes out clean, the idlis are cooked. If not, steam for a few more minutes.
Step 9: Carefully remove the idli tray from the steamer. Let the idlis cool slightly before removing them from the molds.
Step 10: Serve the idlis hot with sambar or South Indian coconut chutney.

recipes.name: Steamed Cilantro and Onion Semolina Cakes with Tangy Tomato Chutney
ingredients: ½ tablespoon Baking soda or 1 teaspoon Eno fruit salt
¼ medium Red onion, finely chopped
directions: Step 1: Prepare the Mustard Seeds and Semolina Batter: Heat ½ tablespoon of canola oil in a small pan. Add mustard seeds and heat until they sputter. Remove from heat and set aside. In a mixing bowl, combine semolina flour, half of the water, yogurt, and half of the sputtered mustard seeds. Mix well, ensuring no lumps. Gradually add the remaining water, 1-2 tablespoons at a time, until the batter reaches a pancake-like consistency. If using baking soda, add it to the batter now. If using Eno fruit salt, wait until just before steaming to add it. Let the batter rest for 10 minutes.

cooking_tips: For a richer flavor, roast the semolina flour lightly before preparing the batter.
Adjust the amount of red pepper powder to control the spice level of the chutney.

recipes.name: Masala Paniyaram
ingredients: 1/2 inch ginger, finely grated or chopped
10-12 curry leaves, torn or finely chopped
directions: Step 1: In a large bowl, combine the idli batter, ginger, onion, green chilies, curry leaves, garam masala (if using), grated coconut, coriander leaves, and salt. Mix well to combine.
Step 2: Heat a paniyaram pan over medium heat. Add a few drops of oil to each mould.
Step 3: Pour a spoonful of batter into each mould, leaving some space at the top.
Step 4: Cook for 3-4 minutes, or until the paniyaram are golden brown on the bottom. Use a wooden skewer or spoon to check the edges for doneness.
Step 5: Gently flip or rotate the paniyaram and cook the other side until golden brown.
Step 6: For crispier paniyaram, flip and cook again briefly. Remove from the pan and cover to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter.
Step 7: Serve the masala paniyaram hot with your favorite chutney.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a plate of golden-brown Masala Paniyaram, crisped edges glistening under soft, directional light.  Focus on the textured surface, highlighting the embedded herbs and spices.  Use a dark, rustic backdrop and wooden serving spoons. Garnish with fresh coriander and grated coconut. Shallow depth of field, focusing on the front paniyaram, creating a blurred background.  Mood: warm, inviting, and appetizing.  Shoot from a slightly elevated angle, showcasing the round shape and individual paniyaram.

video_script.title: Masala Paniyaram: Crispy & Flavorful South Indian Snack
video_script.description: Learn how to make delicious and crispy Masala Paniyaram, a popular South Indian snack, with this easy-to-follow recipe.

scenes.image_prompt: Show a large bowl with idli batter. Add the chopped ginger, onion, green chilies, curry leaves, garam masala, grated coconut, coriander leaves, and salt to the batter.
scenes.voice_over: In a large bowl, combine the idli batter with the chopped ginger, onion, green chilies, curry leaves, garam masala, grated coconut, coriander leaves, and salt. Mix everything well.

scenes.image_prompt: Show a paniyaram pan on a stovetop burner over medium heat. Add a few drops of oil to each mould in the pan.
scenes.voice_over: Heat your paniyaram pan over medium heat. Once hot, add a few drops of oil to each mould. This will prevent sticking and add to the crispy texture.

scenes.image_prompt: Show a spoonful of batter being poured into each mould of the hot paniyaram pan.
scenes.voice_over: Carefully pour a spoonful of batter into each mould, leaving a little space at the top.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the paniyaram cooking in the pan, turning golden brown on the bottom.
scenes.voice_over: Cook for 3-4 minutes until the paniyaram are golden brown and crispy on the bottom. You can use a wooden skewer to check for doneness.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the paniyaram being flipped or rotated in the pan to cook the other side.
scenes.voice_over: Gently flip each paniyaram and cook the other side until golden brown. For extra crispiness, you can flip and cook them briefly a third time.

recipes.name: Indian Gooseberry Rice (Nellikai Sadham)
ingredients: 2 teaspoons chana dal and urad dal powder (or Idli Milagaai Podi)
directions: Step 1: Grate the Indian gooseberries using a vegetable grater.
Step 2: Finely chop the green chilies.
Step 3: Heat the oil in a pan or kadai over medium heat. Add the mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Step 4: Add the grated gooseberries and turmeric powder to the pan. Sauté for 2-3 minutes until the gooseberries soften slightly.
Step 5: Add the chana dal and urad dal powder (or Idli Milagaai Podi) and salt. Sauté for another minute.
Step 6: Gently mix in the cooked rice until it is well combined with the gooseberry mixture.
Step 7: Adjust the salt to taste. Serve hot with chutney or pickle.

video_script.title: Indian Gooseberry Rice (Nellikai Sadham)

recipes.name: Crispy Dosa
ingredients: 1/2 cup Whole Urad Dal (Black Lentils, without skin) or Split Urad Dal
1/2 tablespoon Chana Dal (optional, for golden color)
directions: Step 1: Rinse both types of rice together 3-4 times. Soak in 2 cups of water for 4-5 hours.
Step 2: Rinse urad dal, chana dal, and fenugreek seeds together. Soak in 1 cup water for 4-5 hours.
Step 3: Drain and reserve the water from the urad dal. Grind the drained urad dal, chana dal, and fenugreek seeds in a blender until smooth and fluffy, adding the reserved water as needed.
Step 4: Transfer the urad dal batter to a large container.
Step 5: Grind the drained rice in the blender until smooth, adding water as needed. The rice batter will be slightly grainy.

Step 6: Combine the rice and urad dal batters in the large container. Add salt and mix well. Cover and let ferment at room temperature for 8-10 hours, or overnight. In cold weather, ferment in a warm place.
Step 7: After fermentation, stir the batter. If too thick, add water until it reaches a pouring consistency, slightly thinner than idli batter.
Step 8: Heat a non-stick or iron skillet over medium heat. Sprinkle a few drops of water on the surface; if they sizzle and evaporate quickly, the skillet is ready.
Step 9: Spread 1/2 teaspoon of oil on the hot skillet. Pour a ladleful of batter onto the skillet and swirl it into a thin, round shape (about 7-8 inches in diameter).
Step 10: Drizzle 1 teaspoon of oil around the dosa's edges. Cook for about 2 minutes, until the bottom is light brown and the edges lift.
Step 11: Flip the dosa and cook for 1 minute, or skip this step for thin dosas. Transfer the cooked dosa to a plate. Wipe the skillet with a clean, wet cloth before making the next dosa.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a crispy dosa, golden brown and textured, folded in half or rolled, on a dark slate or rustic wooden surface. Use a shallow depth of field, focusing on the crisp edges and steam escaping. Incorporate a small bowl of sambar and chutney in the background, slightly blurred.  Side lighting should highlight the dosa's airy texture and subtle sheen from the oil. Garnish with fresh cilantro and a scattering of toasted urad dal. The overall mood should be warm, inviting, and slightly rustic.

video_script.title: Crispy Dosa Recipe

scenes.voice_over: Heat a non-stick skillet. Once hot, add oil and pour a ladle of batter, swirling it into a thin circle.

recipes.name: Adai (Lentil and Rice Crepe)
directions: Step 1: Soak the rice and dals (urad, toor, chana, and moong) in water for at least 2-3 hours. Drain and set aside.
Step 2: In a grinder, combine the soaked rice, dals, red chilies, and fennel seeds. Grind to a coarse paste.
Step 3: Transfer the ground mixture to a bowl. Add salt, turmeric powder, and asafoetida. Mix well and set aside.
Step 4: Add the chopped onions, garlic, and coriander leaves to the batter. Mix thoroughly.
Step 5: Add a little water to the batter to achieve a slightly runny consistency, a bit thicker than dosa batter.
Step 6: Heat a dosa tawa or griddle over medium heat.
Step 7: Pour one ladleful of batter onto the hot tawa and spread it into a thin circle like a dosa.
Step 8: Drizzle a little oil around the edges of the adai.
Step 9: Cook for a few minutes until the underside turns golden brown. Flip and cook the other side until golden brown as well.

Use a shallow depth of field, focusing on the textured surface of the top crepe. Backdrop should be a rustic, textured dark brown wall.  Lighting should be soft, directional, and warm, emphasizing the crepe's crisp edges and highlighting the steam rising from the stack. video_script.title: Adai: South Indian Lentil and Rice Crepe
video_script.description: Learn to make Adai, a protein-packed and flavorful South Indian crepe made with lentils and rice. This recipe is easy to follow and perfect for a healthy breakfast or snack.

scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: Various lentils and rice - raw rice, idli rice, urad, toor, chana, and moong dal. Spices - turmeric powder, asafoetida, fennel seeds, and red chilies. And for flavor, onions, garlic, coriander leaves, oil, and salt.

scenes.voice_over: Soak the rice and dals in water for at least 2-3 hours. This softens them for grinding.

scenes.image_prompt: Show rice, dals, red chilies, and fennel seeds being added to a grinder, then a shot of grinding to a coarse paste.
scenes.voice_over: Grind the soaked rice, dals, red chilies, and fennel seeds to a coarse paste. Don't over-grind; a slightly coarse texture is ideal.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the ground mixture in a bowl, and the adding of chopped onions, garlic, coriander leaves, salt, turmeric, and asafoetida.
scenes.voice_over: Add the ground mixture to a bowl. Then, add salt, turmeric powder, asafoetida, chopped onions, garlic, and coriander leaves. Mix everything thoroughly.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the mixing of water with batter. Show the final desired consistency of batter- slightly thicker than dosa batter
scenes.voice_over: Gradually add water to achieve a slightly runny consistency, a bit thicker than dosa batter.

cooking_tips: For a crispier adai, use a well-seasoned cast iron tawa or griddle.

recipes.name: Millet Kara Paniyaram

ingredients.item: mudakathan keerai paste (balloon vine leaves), optional

directions: Step 1: Rinse all the millets, idli rice, urad dal, and fenugreek seeds thoroughly. Soak them in separate bowls for at least 4-6 hours or overnight.
Step 2: Drain the water and grind the urad dal and fenugreek seeds together to a smooth batter, adding water as needed. Transfer to a large bowl.
Step 3: Grind the soaked millets and idli rice separately to a slightly coarse batter. Add this to the urad dal batter.
Step 4: Mix the batters well and let it ferment for 8-10 hours or overnight in a warm place.
Step 5: Once the batter has fermented, prepare the tempering. Heat oil in a pan, add mustard seeds, and let them splutter. Add urad dal and chana dal and fry until golden brown.
Step 6: Add chopped onions, green chilies, grated carrot, and curry leaves to the tempering. Saute until the onions turn translucent.
Step 7: If using, add the mudakathan keerai paste to the tempering and cook for a minute. Add salt to taste.
Step 8: Mix the tempering with the fermented batter.
Step 9: Heat a paniyaram pan and grease each mold with oil. Pour a spoonful of batter into each mold.
Step 10: Cook over medium heat, flipping the paniyaram occasionally, until golden brown and cooked through.
Step 11: Garnish with chopped coriander and serve hot with chutney of your choice.

recipes.name: Oats Uttapam
directions: Step 1: Wash the rice and lentils. Soak the rice, oats, and urad dal in water for 4-5 hours, or until they swell. Add more water if needed, as soaking time may vary depending on humidity and climate.
Step 2: Drain the excess water from the soaked rice, oats, and lentils.
Step 3: Combine the drained ingredients in a blender and grind into a smooth batter. Grind in batches if necessary.
Step 4: Transfer the batter to a large vessel and let it ferment for 6-8 hours, or longer in colder climates.
Step 5: Remove 1 cup of fermented batter and add a pinch of salt. Store the remaining batter in the refrigerator or freezer.
Step 6: Heat a dosa tawa or non-stick pan over medium heat. Grease the pan lightly with oil and wipe with a slice of onion or potato. Add a few more drops of oil.
Step 7: Pour a scoopful of batter onto the hot pan. Do not spread the batter thinly like a dosa. Instead, sprinkle the chopped carrots evenly over the batter.
Step 8: Drizzle a little oil over the carrots and cover the pan with a lid to cook the uttapam evenly.
Step 9: Cook until the edges turn golden brown and crisp. Remove the uttapam gently from the pan.
Step 10: Repeat the process with the remaining batter.
Step 11: Serve hot with coconut chutney and sambar.

video_script.title: Oats Uttapam: A Healthy & Delicious Breakfast

scenes.image_prompt: Show all ingredients neatly arranged on a table: rice, oats, urad dal, carrots, salt, and oil.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: 2 cups of short-grain rice, 1 1/2 cups of rolled oats, 1/2 cup of urad dal, 1/2 cup of finely chopped carrots, salt, and oil.

scenes.image_prompt: Show rice, oats and lentils soaking in separate bowls with water levels clearly visible.
scenes.voice_over: Wash the rice and lentils. Soak the rice, oats, and urad dal in separate bowls with enough water for 4-5 hours or until they swell. Remember, soaking times may vary depending on humidity and climate. Add more water if needed.

scenes.image_prompt: Blender with the drained rice, oats, and lentils being added. Inset image of the smooth, consistent batter.
scenes.voice_over: Drain the soaked ingredients and transfer them to a blender. Grind into a smooth batter, adding water as needed to achieve the right consistency.

scenes.image_prompt: A large vessel containing batter being covered and kept in a warm location for fermentation.
scenes.voice_over: Transfer the batter to a large vessel, cover, and let it ferment for 6-8 hours, or longer in colder climates. Look for small bubbles on the surface, which is a sign that the batter is ready to use.

scenes.image_prompt: Tawa being heated on a medium flame, greased with oil and wiped with an onion slice.
scenes.voice_over: Heat a dosa tawa or non-stick pan over medium heat. Grease the pan lightly with oil and wipe off excess oil with a slice of onion or potato for optimal cooking.

scenes.image_prompt: Pouring batter onto the hot tawa, spreading it to create the round Uttapam base and sprinkling carrots.
scenes.voice_over: Pour a ladleful of batter onto the hot pan and sprinkle the chopped carrots evenly. Don’t spread the batter too thin.

scenes.voice_over: Drizzle a little oil around the Uttapam and cover the pan with a lid. This will cook the Uttapam evenly and help the carrots to soften.

scenes.image_prompt: Uttapam being flipped with a spatula to cook the other side.
scenes.voice_over: Cook for 3-4 minutes, or until the bottom turns golden brown and crispy. Flip and cook the other side for a minute or so.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of final dish: a stack of 2-3 golden-brown oats uttapam, garnished with coriander leaves and served with coconut chutney and sambar.
scenes.voice_over: Serve hot with your favorite chutneys and sambar for a wholesome and satisfying breakfast. Enjoy your healthy Oats Uttapam!

cooking_tips: For crispier uttapams, use a well-seasoned cast iron pan or a non-stick tawa.
Adjust the amount of carrots based on your preference.
If the batter becomes too thick after fermentation, add a little water to adjust the consistency.
